bioghist.p: Harrison Allen (1841-1897) was an American physician and anatomist, born in Philadelphia. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1861, and in 1862 became a surgeon in the United States army and served until the conclusion of the Civil War in 1865. In 1865 he was made professor of comparative anatomy and medical zo√∂logy at the University of Pennsylvania. He was transferred in 1878 to the chair of physiology, which he occupied until 1895. George H. Horn (1840-1897) was a physician and entomologist. He received his Doctor of Medicine degree from the University of Pennsylvania in 1861, and was commissioned as a surgeon in a cavalry unit of the U.S. Army in 1863. He served in the Army in California until 1866. In that year, he returned to Philadelphia, and was elected President of the Entomological Society of Philadelphia. Over the next 30 years, he published 265 scientific papers, establishing 154 new genera and 1582 new species, all while continuing his medical practice as an obstetrician. Edward James Nolan was secretary, librarian, and editor for the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, and was a very active participant in every branch and aspect of the Academy.

scopecontent.p: This is an extra-illustrated memorial volume for Harrison Allen and George H. Horn. The volume includes a copy of published Proceedings of a meeting held in commemoration of Allen and Horn in 1897 and other printed memorials. The volume also includes correspondence from and about the two men, photographic portraits, autographs, and a transcript of Horn's military record. The volume was assembled by Edward J. Nolan.
